stock.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: a supply of a particular type of thing that a shop has available to sell
stock.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: We have a huge stock of quality carpets on sale.
I’m sorry, that swimsuit is completely out of stock in your size.
stock.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: the trading of stocks and shares
stock.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: the total value of all of a company’s shares
stock.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: the total amount of something that is available to be used in a particular area
stock.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: Cod stocks in the North Atlantic have dropped radically.
the stock of housing in rural areas
stock.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: a supply of something that you keep and can use when you need to
stock.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: He keeps a stock of medicines in the cupboard.
The country has been building up its stock of weapons.
stock.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: a liquid made by boiling meat or bones and vegetables, which is used to make soups or to add flavour to other dishes
stock.translation[0].definitions[6].defi: the part of a gun that you hold or put against your shoulder, usually made of wood
stock.translation[0].definitions[8].defi: a plant with pink, white, or light purple flowers and a sweet smell
stock.translation[0].definitions[9].defi: a thick part of a stem onto which another plant can be added so that the two plants grow together
stock.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: if a shop stocks a particular product, it keeps a supply of it to sell
stock.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: We stock a wide range of kitchen equipment.
stock.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: to fill something with a supply of something
stock.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: Our refrigerator at college was always stocked with beer.
stock.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: one of the shares into which ownership of a company is divided, or these shares considered together
stock.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: The company might issue (=make available and sell) stock in order to pay down debt.
Investors are likely to earn superior returns if they hold (=own) stock for five years or longer.
More than 100 companies have filed plans to sell stock to the public for the first time.
The company sold a block of stock (=a large quantity of shares, usually more than 10,000) in the Hong Kong firm to unknown investors.
Stock prices were up in heavy trading.
stock.translation[3].definitions[1].defi: different classes of a company’s stock. Each class has different characteristics, for example the right to vote at shareholders’ meetings
stock.translation[3].definitions[1].exam: The Class B stock carries 10 times the votes of the Class A common stock.
stock.translation[3].definitions[2].defi: one of the bonds sold by a government to finance its BUDGET DEFICIT (=the difference between what it gets in taxes and what it spends). Government bonds are usually considered to be a very safe form of investment
stock.translation[3].definitions[3].defi: a supply of a COMMODITY (=oil, metal, farm product etc) that has been produced and is kept to be used when needed
stock.translation[3].definitions[3].exam: Global stocks (=total stocks in the world) of cocoa amount to 2 million tons, the equivalent of about eight months’ usage.
stock.translation[3].definitions[4].defi: a supply of RAW MATERIALs (=materials for use in manufacturing) or parts before they are used in production, or a supply of FINISHED GOODS
stock.translation[3].definitions[4].exam: If you are going to have a large stock of components you must store them sensibly.
When an unexpected rise in demand occurs, it can be met partly by producing more and partly by running down (=reducing by using) stocks of finished goods.
stock.translation[3].definitions[5].defi: a supply of goods, kept for sale by a shop or other RETAILER
stock.translation[3].definitions[5].exam: Equipment importers had big stocks of last year’s skis and boots still on their hands.
Most children’s bookshops will always have these titles in stock.
A problem with production meant that all the shops were out of stock (=had none of something left).
Distribution control has cut out two layers from the chain, giving greater control of retail stock levels (=quantities in stock).
stock.translation[3].definitions[6].defi: the houses, flats etc available in a particular place
stock.translation[3].definitions[6].exam: The list of discounts offered by housebuilders gets longer as the stock of unsold new homes rises.
Another aspect of housing which merits attention is the condition of the older housing stock.
stock.translation[3].definitions[7].defi: an amount of gold, money etc that a country, company etc has available at a particular time
stock.translation[3].definitions[7].exam: The US gold stock was down $1 million in November to $11.06 billion.
By making goods scarce, high tax policies render the existing stock of money more inflationary.
stock.translation[3].definitions[8].exam: He invested in stock, building up a herd of 1000 cattle.
stock.translation[4].definitions[0].defi: if a shop stocks a particular product, it keeps a supply of it to be sold
stock.translation[4].definitions[0].exam: Independent boutiques that sell expensive clothes are stocking less merchandise as their sales drop.
stock.translation[4].definitions[1].defi: to have a supply of something so that it is ready to be used
stock.translation[4].definitions[1].exam: The parts depot in California is well-stocked (=has lots of parts in stock).
